meta description

I genuinely felt that I kept the commitment and motivation pretty strong throughout the entire five weeks for this exam. This was a project I really enjoyed working with. So I felt pretty devastated the day after the deadline when I realized I had forgotten something so simple and mandatory such as meta description. This was the first thing I wrote down to go back and improve when this course was published.

From previous tutor feedback I have also been told that I can add more context to my meta descriptions, so this is something I kept in mind while adding this.

I reorganized the context in my head element for hierarchy purposes. While doing this I looked over all of the html and scss files to clean it up even more. Because this is our most recent project I chose to do this one last. I needed to separate myself more from this project before I was ready to go back and improve it again.

contactform POST

The course assignment is giving us hints to give level 2 a try, but I don’t believe my project exam is properly designed to include all three optional choices in level 2. It doesn’t make sense to have a comment section on a blog that works as a portfolio for an architect interior designer. And I explained my choices around hashtags filter options quite detailed in my report. But a contact form and newsletter signup that actually works is definitely logic to add.

Because the users can signup several places, I created two different forms in Contact Form 7.

For newsletter signup only email is required and for the normal contact form, name, email, subject and message is required. I used Postman to test with key and value to see if it was able to POST to the different contact form 7 forms.

Going back into the code I noticed a small mistake in my label form. The input had “email” instead of “name” in some places. So I corrected this mistake while working on this.

newsletter post

In my project there are three different ways to sign up visually. You can use the newsletter signup on the frontpage that’s only one of its kind. You can sign up to a newsletter on every other page that has a different colour palette. Or you can go to the contact form under “contact.

Because the styling is slightly different on two of these newsletter sign ups - their names are different on the container and typography. But I kept the id’s the same in the forms that only required a valid email.

When the user submits a valid email address they’ll receive a confirmation popup and I receive the confirmation to my email registered in wordpress.

But if this was real life and actually in use. I would need a checkbox underneath for policy and information about what information we keep about the user in order to follow the GDPR guidelines.

newsletter function


const form = document.querySelector("#confirmation_container");
const email = document.querySelector("#newsletteremail");
const emailError = document.querySelector("#emailError");


function validateForm(event) {
    var pass = true 
    event.preventDefault();

    if (validateEmail(email.value) === true) {
        emailError.style.display = "none";
    } else {
        emailError.style.display = "block";
        pass = false
    }

    if (pass === true) {
        alert("Thank you for signing up to our newsletter!");
        submitData();
        event.target.reset();
    }
}

form.addEventListener("submit", validateForm);

function submitData() {
    fetch ("https://projectexam.zenabi.no/wp-json/contact-form-7/v1/contact-forms/166/feedback", {
        method: "POST",
        body: new FormData(form)
    })
}

function validateEmail(email) {
    const regEx = /\S+@\S+\.\S+/;
    const patternMatches = regEx.test(email);
    return patternMatches;
}

contact form


const form = document.querySelector("#contactForm");
const Name = document.querySelector("#Name");
const nameError = document.querySelector("#nameError");
const subject = document.querySelector("#subject");
const subjectError = document.querySelector("#subjectError");
const email = document.querySelector("#email");
const emailError = document.querySelector("#emailError");
const message = document.querySelector("#message");
const messageError = document.querySelector("#messageError");


function validateForm(event) {
    var pass = true 
    event.preventDefault();

    if (checkLength(Name.value, 4) === true) {
        nameError.style.display = "none";
    } else {
        nameError.style.display = "block";
        pass = false
    }

    if (checkLength(subject.value, 14) === true) {
        subjectError.style.display = "none";
    } else {
        subjectError.style.display = "block";
        pass = false
    }

    if (validateEmail(email.value) === true) {
        emailError.style.display = "none";
    } else {
        emailError.style.display = "block";
        pass = false
    }
    if (checkLength(message.value, 24) === true) {
        messageError.style.display = "none";
    } else {
        messageError.style.display = "block";
        pass = false
    }

    if (pass === true) {
        alert("Thank you for your message! We usually respond within 48 hours.");
        submitData();
        event.target.reset();
    }
}

function submitData() {
    fetch ("https://projectexam.zenabi.no/wp-json/contact-form-7/v1/contact-forms/5/feedback", {
        method: "POST",
        body: new FormData(form)
    })
}


form.addEventListener("submit", validateForm);

function checkLength(value, len) {
    if (value.trim().length > len) {
        return true;
    } else {
        return false;
    }
}

function validateEmail(email) {
    const regEx = /\S+@\S+\.\S+/;
    const patternMatches = regEx.test(email);
    return patternMatches;
}
